cards.title: Northern lights / Breathtaking display over Minnesota

item.title: Northern lights put on breathtaking display over Minnesota
item.trailText: Social media users have uploaded stunning footage of the northern lights appearing much further south than usual
item.standFirst:
Social media users have uploaded stunning footage of the northern lights appearing much further south than usual. aurora borealis has been visible in areas not used to seeing it over the past few days, as has aurora australis in the southern hemisphere. While people on the ground captured footage, astronaut Scott Kelly filmed the view from space

Footage: Chris Broste/CBR Photo/Vicky Mahodaya/Nasa

cards.title: The Guardian film show / Our film critics review Slow West, Going Clear and She's Funny That Way
cards.rawTitle: Our film critics review Slow West, Going Clear and She's Funny That Way

item.title: The Guardian film show: Slow West, Going Clear and She's Funny That Way – video reviews
item.trailText: Our film critics review this week's big releases, including Slow West, a surreal western starring Michael Fassbender as a bounty hunter and Going Clear, Alex Gibney's documentary on Scientology
item.standFirst:
Catherine Shoard and Peter Bradshaw join Xan Brooks for our weekly round-up of the big cinema releases. This week the team ramble off into the weird with Michael Fassbender in surreal lo-fi western Slow West; sing all praises to the great god Xenu with Alex Gibney's Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief; and question whether a comedy about a prostitute with a heart of gold and a lovable, generous John really can mean She's Funny That Way.

• No time for doggone video? Listen to the audio-only version of this week's show
item.byline: Xan Brooks, Catherine Shoard, Peter Bradshaw, Henry Barnes, Dan Susman, Richard Sprenger and Joan Portillo

cards.title: It's 7am at Glastonbury ... fancy a jog?
cards.rawTitle: It's 7am at Glastonbury ... fancy a jog?

item.title: It's 7am at Glastonbury ... fancy a jog?
item.trailText: Every year at Glastonbury, a group of keen runners gets together to enjoy a jog across site. The Guardian's hardened exercise-phobe Leah Green decides to join them
item.standFirst: Every year at Glastonbury, a group of keen runners get together to enjoy a jog across site. Hardened exercise-phobe Leah Green joins them and tries to get into the healthy spirit. Will she manage the five km stretch the morning after the night before?

item.title: Patrick Macnee's life
item.trailText: Macnee was born on 6 February 1922 in London, England to a wealthy and eccentric family. His father gambled away the family fortune, leaving Patrick to be raised by his mother and her female partner
item.standFirst: Macnee was born on 6 February 1922 in London, England to a wealthy and eccentric family. His father Daniel, was a race horse trainer, who drank and gambled away the family fortune, leaving Patrick to be raised by his mother, Dorothea Mary, and her female partner

cards.title: The outsiders / What America doesn't want you to see
cards.rawTitle: What America doesn't want you to see

item.title: The outsiders America doesn't want you to see
item.trailText: Katy Grannan has spent years travelling to the parts of California where tourists do not roam and photographing passing strangers and people living on the fringes of society. Meet the desert dwellers the American Dream forgot
item.standFirst:
Katy Grannan has spent years travelling to the parts of California where tourists do not roam and photographing passing strangers and people living on the fringes of society. Meet the desert dwellers the American Dream forgot

  • The Nine and The Ninety Nine is at Foam gallery, Amsterdam from 26 June to 23 August

cards.title: Sport picture of the day / Historic football, the gentleman's game played by hooligans
cards.rawTitle: Historic football, the gentleman's game played by hooligans

item.title: Sport picture of the day: historic football, the gentleman's game played by hooligans
item.trailText: Calcio Fiorentino, is an early form of football from the 16th century that originated from the ancient roman ‘harpastum’
item.standFirst: Calcio Fiorentino, is an early form of football from the 16th century that originated from the ancient roman ‘harpastum’, and is played in teams of 27, using both feet and hands and allows tactics such as head-butting, punching, elbowing, and choking, but forbids sucker-punching and kicks to the head. Goals can be scored by throwing the ball over a goal running the width of each end of the sand covered field

displayImages.altText: A White Team player, left, is tackled by two Green Team players during their Calcio Fiorentino match in Florence's Piazza Santa Croce.

headerImage.caption: A White Team player, left, is tackled by two Green Team players during their Calcio Fiorentino match in Florence’s Piazza Santa Croce. Photograph: Vincenzo Pinto/AFP/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: A White Team player, left, is tackled by two Green Team players during their Calcio Fiorentino match in Florence's Piazza Santa Croce.
headerImage.cleanCaption: A White Team player, left, is tackled by two Green Team players during their Calcio Fiorentino match in Florence’s Piazza Santa Croce.

image.altText: A White Team player, left, is tackled by two Green Team players during their Calcio Fiorentino match in Florence's Piazza Santa Croce.

cards.title: Readers' photos / The best urban buildings from the movies
cards.rawTitle: The best urban buildings from the movies

item.title: The best urban buildings in the movies – readers' photos
item.trailText: From the HQ of the Gattaca Corporation to the Black Bull pub from Trainspotting, you shared your favourite city buildings in film
item.standFirst:
From the HQ of the Gattaca Corporation to the Black Bull pub from Trainspotting, you shared your favourite city buildings in film

  • Step into my evil modernist lair, Mr Bond
item.body:
Los Angeles’ Bradbury Building in Blade Runner. Gateshead’s Trinity Square car park in Get Carter. That creepy modernist house in Exhibition. Architecture in film can play a significant role, from establishing a time period to powerfully evoking an atmosphere or even shaping the narrative.

We asked you for your favourite examples of urban architecture in film, and you shared silver screen buildings from Paris to Kuala Lumpur (via New York, of course, the home to so many famous movies – and so much famous architecture).

Edinburgh, UK

Related: Step into my evil modernist lair, Mr Bond: the best urban buildings in film

Paris, France

Nottingham, UK

San Rafael, USA

London, UK

Melbourne, Australia

Gateshead, UK

New York, USA

Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

Berlin, Germany

  • Follow Guardian Cities on Twitter and Facebook and join the discussion
